accepted May 23, 1984) Summary The liquid-phase dehydrogenation of methanoi has proved to be possi- ble at a moderate rate through the use of the soluble complex catalysts cis- Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 and Pd^C^dpm)^ under photoirradiation conditions (high-pressure mercury lamp), the addition of acetone accelerating the rate quite noticeably. Quantitative analysis of the reaction products (dihydrogen, formaldehyde, formaldehyde dimethyl acetal, ethylene glycol, 2,3-dimethyl- 2,3-butanediol, 2-propanol, 2-methyl-l,2-propanediol) showed that mass balance for hydrogen was established satisfactorily among them. In com- parison to the acetone-photosensitized reaction of methanoi, the observed product distribution could be characterized as follows: (1) the gas-phase product is almost pure dihydrogen (in comparison to being mainly methane) and (2) the yield of formaldehyde and formaldehyde dimethyl acetal is greatly increased (in comparison to the products being mainly 2-methy 1-1,2- propanediol and ethylene glycol). Introduction The dehydrogenation of methanoi (eqn. (1)) has attracted considerable interest, since the product has the merit of being free from water. CHsOH > HCHO + H, (l) If the reaction proceeds in the liquid phase, very mild conditions can be used for this endothennic process. Although homogeneous complex catalysts for the dehydrogenation of primary or secondary alcohols of high carbon chain length (>C-i) are known [1 - 6], their extension to methanoi has been unsuc- cessful to date. * Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/85/$3.30 Eisevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 260 Previously, we have found that photoirradiation greatly enhances the catalytic activity of rhodium/tin chloride complexes in the dehydrogenation of 2-propanol [7], and we present here the results on the photocatalysis of methanoi dehydrogenation in the presence of some noble metal com- plexes. Experimental All the reagents and solvents were of reagent grade, cis- Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 [8], PdzC^dpm); [9], PdC^dpm) [10], Pt2Cl2(dpm)2 [II], Ir2(jU-S)(CO)2(dpm)2 [12], Mo^dpn^ [13] and Mo2(OAc)4 [14] were all prepared by literature methods (dpm = bis(diphenylphosphino)- methane). A methanoi solution containing an appropriate amount of the catalyst was deaerated by bubbling argon through it previous to reaction. The reactor was equipped with a thermometer and a reflux condenser to which a gas buret was attached. When the refluxing of the solution became stable, mea- surements of the gas-phase volume were commenced. Photo irradiation was carried out using a high-pressure mercury lamp (400 W, Riko Kagaku) con- tained in a Pyrex glass vessel inserted into the reactor. Gas-chromatographic analyses were undertaken using the following stationary phases: (1) molecular sieve 5A and Unibeads IS for the gas-phase components, and (2) Porapak-N and PEG 1000 for low- and high-boiling- point components in the liquid phase, respectively. Quantitative analysis of formaldehyde was performed by means of a colorimetric method [15]. Elec- tronic absorption spectra were measured by use of a recording spectro- photometer (Shimadzu UV-365) with a 1-cm pathlength quartz cell at ambient temperature. "P NMR spectra were obtained with a Fourier trans- form pulsed NMR spectrometer (24.21 MHz, JEOL JNM-FX60Q), the chemical shifts reported being relative to an external 85% H3P04 reference with a negative sign indicating a shift to higher field. Results and discussion In the dark, both cis-Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 and Pd2Cl2(dpm)2 exhibited no catalytic activity (67 C, 12 h; ii^ evolution not detectable by gas chro- matography), However, upon photoirradiation (400 W high-pressure mercury lamp), considerable evolution of gas was observed. The addition of acetone led to a considerable increase in the rate of gas evolution. Gas Chromato- graphie analysis of the gas phase component of the reaction revealed that the evolved gas was composed almost entirely of H2 (with a trace of CH4), in con- trast to the gas-phase products from a 9:1 mixture of methanol/acetone (total volume, 500 ml) under the same photoirradiation conditions where the relative abundances (in %) were 90.0 (CH4), 8.8 (CO) and 1.2 (H2) after a 261 reaction time of 7.5 h. The photo irradiation of methanoi alone led to no reaction at all. Figure 1 shows the typical time course of the photochemical dehydro- genation of methanoi in the presence of a rhodium or palladium complex catalyst. The presence of an induction period as well as the comparatively rapid deactivation of the catalyst should be noted for the palladium catalyst, although a higher activity is attained in this case. Table 1 gives a comparison of the catalytic activity of the two catalysts with and without the addition of acetone; virtually no activity was observed for the palladium catalyst in the absence of acetone. o 20 -( - --((-- 10 20 25 Time / h 30 Fig. l. Time course of the evolution of H; during the dehydrogenation of methanoi in the presence of cis-Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 (n) or Pd^C^dpm^ ( ) catalysts under photoirradia- tion conditions (400 W high-pressure mercury lamp). Catalyst concentration, 0.05 mM (methanoi /acetone ratio 9:1 at a total volume of 500 ml); reaction temperature, 64 C (refluxing). TABLE 1 Liquid-phase photocatalytic dehydrogenation of methanoi3 Catalyst Concentration (mM) Vol. CH3l (ml) of OH Vol. (CH: (ml) of))2CO Reaction temperature ( C) Maximum rate H^ evolution of mmol turno^ h-i h-1 /er Pd2Cl2(dpm)2 ci's-Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 0.05 0.05 0.10 450 450 500 50 60 0 64.0 64.0 65.0 3.90 3.24 0.11 156 130 2.2 ''Photoirradiation with a high-pressure mercury lamp (400 W) at refluxing temperature. 262 In order to elucidate the observed characteristic time-dependence of the photocatalytic activity ofPd^C^dpm)^, the corresponding mononuclear complex, PdCl2(dpm), was prepared and used as a catalyst. It was found that the mononuclear palladium catalyst also showed an induction period, and after exhibiting a maximum activity (95 turnover h~1, based on the total amount of the complex added) began to undergo deactivation some 10 h after the start of photoirradiation. The electronic spectra of the reaction solutions indicated that while the dinuclear and mononuclear complexes gave different spectra even after thermal treatment, photoirradiation con- verted them into a similar species whose absorption spectrum exhibited a shoulder at ca. 420 nm with absorbance expansion into the visible region (colored brown-yellow; Fig. 2). From the nature of its electronic absorption spectrum, this species may be a multinuclear cluster compound (or com- pounds) and it is this cluster which is responsible for the catalytic activity. As the activity of the catalyst decreased, a metallic precipitate gradually appeared. In the rhodium case, where no induction period was observed, the char- acteristic peak of c;'s-Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 (Xmax = 441 nm) persisted through- out the whole photoreaction period (Fig. 3). It is, however, noticeable from Fig. 3 that the absorbance also gradually expands into the visible with this e 0.4 400 450 Wavelength / mil 400 450 Wavelength / nm Fig. 2. Electronic absorption spectra of the reaction solution (methanol/acetone ratio 9:1 at a total volume of 500 ml) containing palladium complex catalysts. (1) Pd^Cl^dpm)^ (0.06 mM) after thermal reaction for 2 h, (2) following a further period of photoirradia- tion (4.5 h) and (3) after prolonged photoirradiation leading to deactivation (15 h). (4) PdCl2(dpm) (0.10 mM) after thermal reaction for 2 h, (5) following a further period of photoirradiation (4.5 h) and (6) after prolonged photoirradiation leading to deactivation (21 h). The reaction temperature was 64 C (refluxing). Fig. 3. Electronic absorption spectra of the reaction solution (methanol/acetone ratio 9:1 at a total volume of 500 ml) containing rhodium complex catalysts. (1) ci's- Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 (0.05 mM) before and after thermal reaction (2 h) and (2) following a further period of photoirradiation (9.5 h). The reaction temperature was 64 C (refluxing). 263 catalyst as well. In this case after prolonged photoirradiation, the absorption expansion became so marked as to exceed the original absorbance at 441 nm. Concentration and drying of this solution in vacuo gave a black-brown solid which was completely soluble in CHzClz. The "P NMR spectrum of this CHiCl; solution at room temperature exhibited three major peaks with 6 values ('JRhp values in Hz) of 18.1 (115), 18.9 (114) and 19.7 (117) ppm, respectively. Since cis-Rh^Cl^(CO)y,(dpm)^ gives a doublet at 25.4 ppm (^Rhp = 103 Hz) at room temperature (fluxional), the three observed peaks may be ascribed to cluster compounds. Since no peak corresponding to uncoordinated dpm was detectable in the spectrum, the formation of metallic rhodium at this stage appears most unlikely. After the reaction, the following products were shown to be present in the liquid phase: formaldehyde (1), formaldehyde dimethyl acetal (2), ethylene glycol (3), 2,3-dimethyl-2,3-butanediol (4), 2-propanol (5) and 2- methyl-l,2-propanediol (6). In order that products 1 -6 should be formed, the processes of dehydrogenation, C C coupling and intermolecular hydro- gen transfer must be involved in a complex manner. From the viewpoint of mass balance for hydrogen, the products can be formally classified as in Scheme 1. A quantitative analysis of the amounts of products formed gave Reactions involving the generation of dihydrogen CH30H > Hi + HCHO (1) 3 CHaOH > H2 + CH2(OCH3)2 + ii^O (2) 2 CH30H > H2 + HOCHzCHiOH (3) Reactions involving the consumption of dihydrogen 2 (CH3)2CO + H2 > HOC(CH3)2C(CH3)20H (4) (CH3)2CO + H2 > (CH3)2CHOH (5) Hydrogen transfer reaction CH30H + (CH3)2CO > HOCH2C(CH3)20H (6) Scheme 1. 264 TABLE 2 Product distribution obtained in the liquid-phase photocatalytic dehydrogenation of m'ethano^ Catalyst 1 2 3 1+2+3 Ha 4 5 Hz+4+56 PdzCl^dpm);11 19.5 13.7 3.5 36.7 35.3 0.2 1.7 37.2 3.2 cis-Rh-tCl^COUdpm^ 7.8 4.1 15.3 27.2 23.1 0.9 7.7 31.7 9.4 "Formed amounts (in mmol) under photoirradiation conditions (400 W high-pressure mercury lamp) at 64 C (refluxing). Catalyst concentration in a 9:1 methanol/acetone mixture (total volume, 500 ml) was 0.05 mM. The numbering of the product is that used in Scheme 1. b Reaction time, 15 h. "Reaction time, 9.5 h. the product distribution tabulated in Table 2. In view of the error limit (^3%) involved in the analysis of each product, the postulated stoichiometry for hydrogen seems to be satisfactory. The product distribution in Table 2 is quite different from that obtained by photoirradiation of a 9:1 methanol/acetone mixture (total vol- ume, 500 ml) alone under the same reaction conditions (when the relative abundances (in %) were 0.9 (1), 29.0 (3), 4.4 (4), 27.5 (5) and 38.2 (6) with a reaction time of 7.5 h) and shows a marked preference for 1 (+ 2) over the other products. Thus, it is evident that the catalyst does participate in the overall reaction, even if the emission from the high-pressure mercury lamp contributes in part in exciting acetone (n ff*) as an initial step in the photo- chemical process. As far as the selectivity to 1 (+ 2) is concerned, the higher value in the presence of the palladium catalyst is noteworthy. The rate of H^ evolution has been determined for both methanoi and 2-propanol [16] at various temperatures, using the rhodium catalyst which showed relatively constant catalytic activity (cf. Fig. 1). From the resulting Arrhenius plot (Fig. 4), the apparent activation energies may be calculated as 26.4 and 14.3 kJ mol"1 for methanoi and 2-propanol, respectively. These values appear to reflect the higher C H bond dissociation energy [17] of methanoi (393 kJ mol"1) relative to 2-propanol (381 kJ mol"1 for Me^C H), indicating an increased difficulty for methanoi dehydrogenation. We have also tried to dehydrogenate methanoi using Pt^Cl^dpm)^, Ir2(JU-S)(CO)2(dpm)2, Mo^CI^(dpm)^ or Mo2(OAc)4 as the catalyst. None of these complexes exhibited any thermal catalytic activity and photoirradia- tion was not so effective as in the cases of the rhodium and palladium com- plexes. It is of interest, however, that the iridium and platinum complexes showed an activity pattern which was respectively similar to the rhodium and palladium complexes. Thus Ir2(JU-S)(CO)2(dpm)2 exhibited photo- catalytic activity in the absence of acetone (0.05 mM solution of methanoi of total volume 500 ml; turnover frequency for H^ formation, 1.4 h"1), the color of the solution changing from purple to brown-yellow upon illumina- tion. In the presence of added acetone, the gas-phase product was a mixture 265 0.8 0.6 0.4 0.2 -0-2 " Us 2.9 3.0 3.1 3.2 3.3 103 T"1 / K'1 Fig. 4. The temperature dependence of the rate of H^ evolution in the presence of Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 as the catalyst under photoirradiation conditions (400 W high- pressure mercury lamp), o: for a 9:1 methanol/acetone mixture (total volume, 500 ml; catalyst concentration, 0.05 mM); n: for a 9:1 2-propanol/acetone mixture (total volume, 500 ml .catalyst concentration, 0.05 mM). of CH4 and Ha (with CO being not detectable). In contrast, Pt^C^dpm); showed no photocatalytic activity in the absence of acetone (28 h irradia- tion) while with a 9:1 methanol/acetone mixture (total volume, 500 ml), a maximum turnover frequency for H 2 formation of 30 h~1 was observed. The two molybdenum catalysts showed no appreciable photocatalytic activity towards H 3 formation. It appears that considerable scope for improving the catalyst for methanoi dehydrogenation in the liquid phase remains. References 1 H. B. Channan, y. Chem. Soc. B, (1970) 584. 2 A. Dobson and S. D. coredata.dc:description: The liquid-phase dehydrogenation of methanol has proved to be possible at a moderate rate through the use of the soluble complex catalysts cis-Rh2 Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 and Pd2Cl2(dpm)2 under photoirradiation conditions (high-pressure mercury lamp), the addition of acetone accelerating the rate quite noticeably. Quantitative analysis of the reaction products (dihydrogen, formaldehyde, formaldehyde dimethyl acetal, ethylene glycol, 2,3-dimethyl2, 3-butanediol, 2-propanol, 2-methyl-1,2-propanediol) showed that mass balance for hydrogen was established satisfactorily among them. In comparison to the acetone-photosensitized reaction of methanol, the observed product distribution could be characterized as follows: (1) the gas-phase product is almost pure dihydrogen (in comparison to being mainly methane) and (2) the yield of formaldehyde and formaldehyde dimethyl acetal is greatly increased (in comparison to the products being mainly 2-methy 1-1,2propanediol and ethylene glycol).
coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic dehydrogenation of methanol in the liquid phase with cis-Rh2Cl2(CO)2(dpm)2 and Pd2Cl2(dpm)2 complex catalysts
